text.p: Note that, in particular, the space [mathjaxinline]\mathbb {P}[/mathjaxinline] contains [mathjaxinline]\mathbb {P}_4[/mathjaxinline] as a subspace, so we can arrive at the same conclusion about the dimension of [mathjaxinline]\mathbb {P}[/mathjaxinline] as we did for [mathjaxinline]V[/mathjaxinline] in the previous question.

However, [mathjaxinline]\mathbb {P}[/mathjaxinline] also contains [mathjaxinline]\mathbb {P}_{40}[/mathjaxinline], [mathjaxinline]\mathbb {P}_{400}[/mathjaxinline], and [mathjaxinline]\mathbb {P}_{4000}[/mathjaxinline] as subspaces (among others). What can we conclude about the dimension of [mathjaxinline]\mathbb {P}[/mathjaxinline]?

optioninput.options: ('It has dimension 5','It has dimension 41','It has dimension 4001','It is infinite dimensional')

font.p: Since [mathjaxinline]\mathbb {P}[/mathjaxinline] contains [mathjaxinline]\mathbb {P}_{4000}[/mathjaxinline] (a 4001-dimensional space) as a subspace, it must have dimension at least 4001. However, note that we can replace the number 4000 by any positive integer [mathjaxinline]n[/mathjaxinline]. The dimension of [mathjaxinline]\mathbb {P}[/mathjaxinline] must be at least [mathjaxinline]n+1[/mathjaxinline] for any such [mathjaxinline]n[/mathjaxinline]. The only way this is possible if if [mathjaxinline]\mathbb {P}[/mathjaxinline] has no finite dimension.
